results.title: An Interview with Valda Maskell and Alf
results.creator_credit: Alfred Maskell, Valda Maskell and ACMI
results.brief_description: Valda Maskell, with the assistance of her husband Alfred, gives a touching account of how their love for each other survived World War 2. Valda met Alfred in Bendigo and they managed to get engaged just before Alfred was despatched to Malaya to fight the Japanese. The story is mostly told from Valda’s perspective, how she joined the RAAF and worked there as a cook and how she spent three years working there, all the while knowing nothing of Alfred’s fate. On his return, Valda promptly went AWOL, married Alfred and shares with us the ups and downs of her life with a returned soldier, who was also a prisoner of war.

On his return, Valda promptly went AWOL, married Alfred and shares with us the ups and downs of her life with a returned soldier, who was also a prisoner of war.

results.title: When war came to Australia
results.creator_credit: Bill Hosking, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A recent visit to Darwin with his son reminded Bill Hosking of the time that war came to Australia. As one of the men who defended Darwin during that time, he was instructed to keep the details of the attack secret. In 1942, Bill Hosking joined up and was shipped up to train in the Northern Territory. It was during this time that the air raids on Darwin took place. Bill shares his experiences because he believes that not many people today know the story of how Australia came under attack.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Hosking, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Interview with Arthur Harridge
results.brief_description: Even though Arthur Harridge believes each service being as important as the other, he was primarily an airforce man. He tells of leaving his home and loved ones aboard the Mariposa, bound for the United States and then Europe, where he experienced the horrors of war first hand. An emotional account of the horrors of war, the things that kept the soldiers going returning home and trying to forget.

results.title: An Interview with Alfred Maskell
results.brief_description: Alfred Maskell just wanted to see the world. In 1941, he joined the Australian army and was sent to Malaya. By the time he got there, it was clear the Australian forces were up against it, fighting a strong enemy with weaponry from the previous World War. By the end of the year they were captured by the Japanese and forced to perform many unsavoury tasks, from burying Chinese civilians to working on the Thai-Burma railway and, finally, in Japan where he stayed till the war ended. This is a story of the brutality that many prisoners of war suffered during World War 2.

results.title: The Letters from Java
results.brief_description: Eric Peters only knew his dad through what records were left behind. They were mostly letters that came through the censors at a POW camp in Burma and old photos. He reflects on the sadness of not knowing his dad and the importance of bringing his spirit home to rest.
results.description: Eric Peters only knew his dad through what records were left behind. They were mostly letters that came through the censors at a POW camp in Burma and old photos. He reflects on the sadness of not knowing his dad and the importance of bringing his spirit home to rest.

results.title: Compression
results.brief_description: Ricky Morris is the 21st member of his family to see active service for Australia. He is proud to be part of the fighting Gunditjmarra people. His story looks at the invisible pressures modern soldiers constantly face and his realisation that this was shared by his family waiting for him at home.
results.description: Ricky Morris is the 21st member of his family to see active service for Australia. He is proud to be part of the fighting Gunditjmarra people. His story looks at the invisible pressures modern soldiers constantly face and his realisation that this was shared by his family waiting for him at home.

results.title: Back to being black
results.brief_description: John Lovett reflects on the injustices experienced by his father and so many other indigenous war veterans who were not recognised or afforded the same benefits as their white mates when they returned from service.
results.description: John Lovett reflects on the injustices experienced by his father and so many other indigenous war veterans who were not recognised or afforded the same benefits as their white mates when they returned from service.

results.title: Time to fly
results.creator_credit: Liam O'Bree, Belle Willox and ACMI
results.brief_description: Belle Willox joined the WAAAFs because she always wanted to be a flyer like Amy Johnson. She joined when she was 18 and, though she never got to pilot a plane herself, there were certainly many ups and downs during her time in the war.
results.description: Belle Willox joined the WAAAFs because she always wanted to be a flyer like Amy Johnson. She joined when she was 18 and, though she never got to pilot a plane herself, there were certainly many ups and downs during her time in the war.
